context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: What's on TV tonight: Requiem and Flint Town
context_meta.summary: Friday 2 March Requiem BBC One, 9.00pm After last week’s hiatus because of the Six Nations rugby, it’s back to small-town Wales for another dose of supernatural country-house shenanigans.  When we last saw fragile but determined musician Matilda (Lydia Wilson), she’d suffered the double whammy of finding her would-be mother Rose (Claire Rushbrook) unconscious in the bath and learning that mute Aunt Meredith (Jane Thorne) had died on the verge of offering up her secrets. How did Matilda react? By mysteriously blacking out and bashing her beloved cello against a cupboard.  In the fourth episode then, she looks for connections between her mental health and Carys’s disappearance. And some clues emerge: Matilda meets dishevelled local Laura (Anastasia Hille), who claims to hear voices informing her of Carys’s fate, and back at the mansion, she comes across some old tomes detailing rituals to unlock the past. Even with its heavily scored bumps and shudders, Requiem can’t quite sustain its early Hammer Horror appeal. The strong performances and some genuinely chilling moments keep things compelling however, not least in the spine-tingling climax of this episode. Toby Dantzic Flint Town Netflix, from today Back in 2014, a cost-cutting exercise left thousands of homes in Flint, Michigan, with contaminated drinking water for years. This new eight-part documentary looks at the fallout from the crisis through the eyes of Flint’s beleaguered police force, who face an uphill struggle – the community needs their support but are also deeply mistrustful of those in authority, plus dwindling resources makes the officers’ jobs harder still.  MasterChef BBC One, 7.30pm Having survived the cooking contest’s opening week, the six heat winners face food critic William Sitwell in this first quarter-final. He challenges them to conjure up a standout pudding showcasing either alcohol or spices. Love Your Garden ITV, 8.00pm; not STV/UTV/Wales This week, Alan Titchmarsh and his team are in Bidewell, Devon, helping Tamsyn and Alex Wood who returned to the UK from France after Alex suffered a brain injury. The aim is to turn the Woods’ garden into a coastal sanctuary inspired by Alex’s passion for surfing.  The Yorkshire Steam Railway: All Aboard Channel 5, 8.00pm As amiable as its title suggests, this new documentary series follows the lives of those who work on the North Yorkshire Moors Railway, one of the country’s most popular steam railways. In this series’ opener, the new season begins with the arrival of star engine Royal Scot, on loan from London.  Tones, Drones and Arpeggios: The Magic of Minimalism BBC Four, 9.00pm Conductor Charles Hazlewood explores minimalism, which he argues is the most important musical form of the 20th century. In the fascinating opener of this two-part series, he unpicks the construction of these sometimes confounding sounds and tracks down the genre’s avant-garde pioneers, who brought their mesmeric, spirituality-inspired compositions from California to New York in the Sixties. TD Jo Brand: Secrets of Her Success Channel 5, 10.30pm Channel 5’s celebration of funny women continues with this absorbing profile of the pioneering doyenne of deadpan, Jo Brand. This charts her career from its rocky start on the male-dominated stand-up circuit to her much-admired hospital sitcom Getting On. TD Gladiator (2000) ★★★★★ Film4, 9.00pm This take on the traditional swords-and-sandals epic proved that Russell Crowe deserved to be recognised as a mainstream star, and reaffirmed Ridley Scott’s reputation as a first-rate director. Crowe is Maximus, a former Roman general who rebuilds his career as a gladiator. His bid for vengeance against a vile emperor (Joaquin Phoenix) is compelling. Plus there’s a last hurrah from Oliver Reed. Blades of Glory (2007) ★★★☆☆ BBC One, 11.05pm; Wales, 11.35pm;N Ireland, 12.05am You might think that the sequinned world of figure skating is beyond parody, but here Will Ferrell and Jon Heder serve up a zestfully preposterous comedy. Both play rival Olympic ice skaters, Ferrell a loose-living maverick, Heder a prissy perfectionist, who are slung out of the sport but use a loophole to return as an erotic all-male pairing. Amy Poehler co-stars. A Hijacking (2012) ★★★★☆ BBC Two, 11.55pm Tobias Lindholm’s vigorously intelligent hostage thriller, set on board a besieged ship in the Indian Ocean, deftly moves his story between the boat and the shipping company’s offices, where Søren Malling’s frazzled CEO attempts to thrash out a bargain. On the other end of the line is the Somalis’ translator. Flies buzz, sweat trickles, negotiations continue, and you feel your breath dry up. Saturday 3 March Pamela Anderson and Piers Morgan Credit: ITV Piers Morgan’s Life Stories ITV, 9.50pm Piers Morgan puts questions to Pamela Anderson, the model famous for wearing a red swimsuit on Baywatch and for appearing on the cover of Playboy more times than anyone else. To her credit, Anderson is also a fervent animal rights campaigner who convinced Vladimir Putin to ban imports of seal products into Russia. Morgan does ask her about Putin, but his focus is firmly on a sex tape that was made public and whether Anderson has slept with her friend Julian Assange. Despite Morgan’s jovial approach, he doesn’t give her an easy ride, which means that the show’s tone zigzags between a soft chat and an awkward interview. Anderson makes self-deprecating quips about her multiple marriages, although there’s an interesting revelation about a run-in with Harvey Weinstein when she refused to work with a dog in one of his films. It’s left largely to Anderson’s friends – among them Vivienne Westwood – appearing in pre-recorded videos to try to provide insight into her psyche. Anderson is an interesting figure, but despite Morgan’s best efforts, the only bombshell, for want of a better word, in this programme is the one sat opposite him. VP Ant & Dec’s Saturday Night Takeaway ITV, 7.00pm Ant and Dec’s madcap variety show celebrates its 100th episode tonight. Despite having entered their forties and being dogged by some personal troubles, the Geordie duo’s playful charisma remains undimmed. This episode sees Cuba Gooding Jr and Alfie Boe among the guest stars. VP All Together Now BBC One, 7.15pm The BBC’s latest sing-a-thon reaches its climax, with the 10 finalists competing for a £50,000 prize. Although Rob Beckett’s quips have provided some levity, the format hasn’t captured the imagination. So, the BBC’s search for an adequate replacement for The Voice continues. VP Britain at Low Tide Channel 4, 8.00pm Tori Herridge presents more tales from the riverbank when she investigates the Clyde’s Iron Age heritage. Part travelogue, part history lesson, this episode is a compelling jaunt through Glasgow’s maritime past. VP Troy: Fall of a City BBC One, 9.10pm BBC One’s ambitious sex-and-sandals epic continues, with Hector and Paris (Tom Weston-Jones and Louis Hunter) undertaking a risky mission to Cilicia to ask for help in breaking the Greeks’ blockade of Troy. Meanwhile, in Troy, the cause of all the trouble, Helen (Bella Dayne), makes a selfless gesture to win the people’s favour. VP Modus BBC Four, 9.00pm and 9.45pm The second run of this Swedish murder-mystery series has veered from its Scandi-noir roots to spin an implausible espionage tale. Still, it’s had some enjoyably twisty moments, along with Greg Wise in full panto-villain mode as odious FBI agent Warren Schifford. This double-bill brings the series to an end, with detective Ingvar Nyman (Henrik Norlén) forced to team up with Schifford to find the US President (Kim Cattrall). VP Mosaic Sky Atlantic, 10.00pm The pace picks up in Steven Soderbergh’s small-town crime thriller as a breakthrough in the Olivia Buckland (Sharon Stone) murder causes chief detective Nate Henry (Devin Ratray) to panic. Four years after Eric’s incarceration for the murder, his sister Petra (Jennifer Ferrin) hounds Henry into taking a fresh look at the case. The introduction of Beau Bridges as an ex-police chief brings even more lustre to this stylish whodunit. VP 10 Cloverfield Lane (2016) ★★★★☆ Channel 4, 9.00pm Michelle (Mary Elizabeth Winstead) wakes in a room with her leg chained to a pipe. Her host is Howard (John Goodman), a quick-tempered survivalist type with a stockpile of food and an appetite for armageddon. Is this a thriller, a puzzle, or a monster movie? Producer JJ Abrams’s vice-like spiritual successor to Cloverfield keeps you guessing until the end.  The Help (2011) ★★★★☆ BBC Two, 11.20pm; not Wales Emma Stone sparkles among the fine female cast in this enjoyable adaptation of Kathryn Stockett’s 2009 novel. She stars as a budding journalist working in Sixties Jackson, Mississippi, who convinces two black maids (Viola Davis and the Oscar-winning Octavia Spencer) to work secretly with her on a book and reveal the hardships inflicted on them. Bryce Dallas Howard is a delightfully hissable villain. My Brother the Devil (2012)  ★★★☆☆ BBC One, 11.55pm; Scotland, 12.40am A gritty coming-of-age story about two Muslim brothers. Swaggering gang member Rash (James Floyd) is king of his particular hill in Hackney, and mentor and protector of his younger brother Mo (Fady Elsayed). Rash wants to use his drug money to put Mo through college, but an encounter with a photographer named Sayyid opens up a whole new world of possibilities. Sunday 4 March Lady Doris Castlerosse Credit: Channel 4 Churchill’s Secret Affair Channel 4, 8.00pm “In future, no historian will be able to ignore the tale of Winston and Doris” is too great a claim to make at the close of this documentary. But the question of whether or not Britain’s wartime hero Winston Churchill had an affair with Lady Doris Castlerosse in the south of France during the summer of 1934 certainly makes for an engrossing hour. Admittedly, the hard evidence on offer is non-existent. Most of the story is founded on a remark made by Churchill’s former private secretary, Sir John “Jock” Colville, in a taped interview in 1985, which was recently unearthed again. Still, historians Warren Dockter and Richard Toye put together a pretty compelling circumstantial case for Churchill engaging in a dalliance at the very least with Lady Castlerosse, a fabulously glamorous social-climbing member of the pre-war “Riviera set”. And the story is backed up by at least one member of her family, niece Caroline Delevingne (who also happens to be the aunt of supermodel Cara Delevingne). Some of the most intriguing speculation focuses on three portraits Churchill painted of Doris, and why he might have desperately wanted them back. GO Hold the Sunset BBC One, 7.30pm Three episodes in and, for a comedy, Hold the Sunset still rather light on laughs despite the powerhouse cast. Tonight, when Edith (Alison Steadman) and Phil (John Cleese) seize the chance to get away for the weekend, Queenie (Anne Reid) spies an opportunity for a party. GO Call the Midwife BBC One, 8.00pm As Barbara (Charlotte Ritchie) is moved into Poplar Hospital’s isolation wing, Dr Turner (Stephen McGann) and Shelagh (Laura Main) get a little too close to a young offender who has discovered that his wife is pregnant. GO Top Gear BBC Two, 8.00pm Matt LeBlanc and Chris Harris head to California to try out some muscle-bound off-roaders. Meanwhile, the new McLaren 720S proves a heart-stopper on the track, and comedian Lee Mack reveals his petrol-head credentials. Also, there’s Top Gear: Extra Gear at 10.50pm. GO Strike: Career of Evil BBC One, 9.00pm By the close last week, Strike (Tom Burke) was barely any closer to finding out who sent Robin (Holliday Grainger), his partner in crime detection, an amputated leg. But someone was doing a fine job of setting him up for the murder of its former owner. Tonight, Robin gets into hot water when another body part turns up in her kitchen. GO Bob Monkhouse: Million Joke Man Yesterday, 7.00pm Paul O’Grady hosts this glowing tribute to Bob Monkhouse, a “towering talent” who was a “writer, cartoonist, actor, radio and TV presenter, comedian and the most prolific gameshow host ever”. O’Grady also gets access to Monkhouse’s legendary hand-written joke books, in which he meticulously recorded every gag he crafted. GO Oscars 2018 Sky Cinema Oscars, from 11.00pm With lots of home interest (Darkest Hour, Dunkirk, Gary Oldman, Sally Hawkins, Lesley Manville among them), there will be plenty staying up all night to follow the results live. Sky’s dedicated channel has it all, including an entertaining potted history The Oscars: Greatest Shocks, Frocks and Fairytales (11.00pm), followed by all the glamorous arrivals action on Red Carpet Live (midnight) and, finally, the ceremony itself, The 90th Annual Academy Awards (1.30am), once again hosted by Jimmy Kimmel. GO Captain America: The First Avenger (2011) ★★★☆☆ E4, 6.30pm Sickly Steve Rogers (Chris Evans) volunteers for a project during the Second World War in which he is transformed into America’s hulking secret weapon, a “super-soldier”. Joe Johnston’s film is based on the Forties Marvel comics and, although it doesn’t exactly enthral, the action scenes are terrific fun. The similarly enjoyable sequel, The Winter Soldier, is on Friday, BBC One at 11.05pm. Baby Driver (2017) ★★★★★ Sky Cinema Premiere, 8.00pm Edgar Wright’s infectious car-chase thriller, about a getaway-driving cutie-pie savant (Ansel Elgort, bringing a physical musicality to every on-screen task) whose every move behind the wheel is in Olympic-level sync with whichever song is pulsing in his iPod earbuds, will make you believe in magic. The editing is stunning and keeps the film a hop and skip apart from its forebears. Chocolat (2000) ★★★★☆ ITV3, 10.00pm Lasse Hallström’s warm adaptation of Joanne Harris’s 1999 novel stars Juliette Binoche as the free spirit who sets up a decadent chocolate shop in a stuffy French village. Just as her confections are melting local hearts, her relationship with a gypsy living at a nearby camp threatens their tolerance. With Johnny Depp playing the rogue, though, who can blame her. Alfred Molina and Judi Dench co-star. Monday 5 March Philip Pullman  Credit: BBC Imagine: Philip Pullman: Angels and Daemons BBC One, 10.45pm; Northern Ireland, 11.40pm “I felt that I’d been preparing for something, that I’d been serving a long apprenticeship,” says children’s author Philip Pullman of his most famous works, the His Dark Materials trilogy, a statement which helps explain why these particular books have enthralled readers since the publication of Northern Lights, the first in the series, in 1995.  The dry, delightful Pullman makes for the best possible subject for Imagine… He’s informed, opinionated, both realistic and romantic, and endlessly curious about the world. Here we hear about his early years in Wales with his clergyman grandfather who gave him “the sense that the world was full of stories”. We also hear about Pullman’s time as a teacher, which was when he honed his craft by teaching his pupils Greek mythology. His atheism is touched on – “human beings themselves are quite sufficient to explain both good and evil” – although sensibly not allowed to overwhelm the film. Instead, Pullman discusses the influence of John Milton on his writing before coming down on the side of another great visionary: “I wouldn’t be the writer I am without William Blake,” he says with a smile. This is an altogether magical documentary. SH Classic Mary Berry BBC One, 8.30pm The unflappable Mary Berry heads to London to visit a school with a secret garden. There, the pupils grow vegetables and look after chickens. She also supervises a keen pair of Year 5 pupils as they prepare school lunch. SH Collateral BBC Two, 9.00pm David Hare’s compelling yet infuriating drama reaches its conclusion as DI Kip Glaspie (Carey Mulligan) pulls it all together, even as army captain Sandrine (Jeany Spark) faces her demons. Meanwhile, John Simm’s MP has a clunky confrontation with his party leader and a rather better one with his ex-wife (Billie Piper). SH Marcella ITV, 9.00pm Things get even murkier this week as Jason (Nicholas Pinnock) gives ex-wife Marcella (Anna Friel) some unwanted news, which causes her to struggle both at work and at home. Thank goodness then for DC LeAnn Hunter (Sophia Brown), who injects some welcome common sense into proceedings. SH Electric Dreams: Autofac Channel 4, 10.00pm This week’s instalment of the sci-fi anthology follows Juno Temple’s idealistic computer hacker working in a collapsing AI-dominated world. When she comes into conflict with a PR robot named Alice (an excellent Janelle Monáe), there’s revolution in the air. SH This Country BBC Three/BBC iPlayer, from 10.00am The countryside comedy goes from strength to strength with an entertaining second episode that sees Kurtan (Charlie Cooper) indoctrinated into the secret ways of labouring by Kerry’s (Daisy May Cooper) dad. The first episode is on BBC One tomorrow at 10.45pm. SH Active Shooter: America Under Fire Sky Atlantic, 9.00pm This series on mass shootings in the US comes to an end with an episode about the 1999 massacre at Columbine school in Colorado, which, following the shooting in Florida last month, no longer stands as the worst high-school shooting in US history. The matter is sensitively handled, as journalist Dave Cullen debunks the theory that the perpetrators were “depressed outcasts”. But, most importantly, the focus is on the victims and survivors, such as the school’s principal and Jefferson County’s head investigator, who discuss how their lives have changed. SH Thoroughly Modern Millie (1967) ★★★☆☆ Film4, 11.00am George Roy Hill directed two of the most popular films ever: Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid (1969) and The Sting (1973). But this indifferent Julie Andrews musical of the flapper era came first. There’s much to enjoy in the story of a naive woman who leaves her rural roots behind to seek fortune and romance in Twenties New York. James Fox, as a spiffing salesman, is a particular highlight. Carol (2015) ★★★★★ Film4, 9.00pm Todd Haynes’s adaptation of Patricia Highsmith’s 1952 novel is gorgeous, gently groundbreaking, and quite possibly be the saddest thing that you’ll ever see. It tells the story of a photographer (Rooney Mara) who has a relationship with an older woman (Cate Blanchett, with a subtlety that’s little short of phenomenal) in New York. Haynes’s film concludes that love is the riskiest but most necessary gamble in anyone’s experience. Nacho Libre (2006) ★★☆☆☆ ITV4, 12.05am There are some terrific sight gags in this silly comedy but one might have expected more from Jack Black (who was so good in School of Rock, Shallow Hal and High Fidelity) and the director of Napoleon Dynamite, Jared Hess. Black plays Ignacio, a friar in a Mexican orphanage who, to raise money, moonlights as a Mexican wrestler. He battles some tough opponents, but none as fierce as the monastery’s opprobrium for the sport. Television previewers Toby Dantzic, Sarah Hughes, Gerard O'Donovan, Vicki Power and Gabriel Tate

context_meta.title: LIONSGATE JOINS FORCES WITH FACEBOOK ON KIM KARDASHIAN WEST'S 'YOU KIDDIN' ME'
context_meta.summary: SANTA MONICA, Calif. and VANCOUVER, British Columbia, March 2, 2018 /PRNewswire/ -- Continuing to ramp up its premium unscripted business, global content leader Lionsgate (NYSE: LGF.A, LGF.B) today announced a partnership with Facebook to bring the nonfiction series You Kiddin' Me to the social network's Facebook Watch video platform. The ten-episode series, produced by Lionsgate, will be executive produced by Kim Kardashian West, Jennifer O'Connell, Brian Tannenbaum, Peter M. Cohen, and Melissa Stokes.

context_meta.title: NBC will cut back on ads during primetime to lure more viewers
context_meta.summary: If you've been irritated by the increase of commercials into primetime programming, you're not alone. Now, NBCUniversal is doing something about it across its networks. The number of ads in a commercial break will be reduced by 20 percent, while the amount of ad time in a given show will decrease by 10 percent, according to Variety.

context_meta.title: 842 lbs man from 'My 600-lb Life' dead
context_meta.summary: Robert Buchel, who appeared on the TLC show "My 600 Pound Life" has died. The New Jersey resident, who weighed 842 pounds, was featured on Wednesday night's episode where viewers learned he suffered a heart attack during the filming of the show. Buchel had undergone weight loss surgery and was placed on a strict diet before he died suddenly of a heart attack on Nov. 17, 2017. Fans only learned of his death last night. "TLC was deeply saddened by the loss of Robert. We are grateful to his family who were gracious enough to let us continue to share his brave story with our viewers," TLC told Fox News. "Our thoughts and prayers are with them at this difficult time." Buchel's fiancee Kathryn said

context_meta.title: Why Did Disney’s CEO Compensation Decline in 2017?
context_meta.summary: Robert Iger, the Walt Disney (DIS) CEO (chief executive officer) who last year extended his contract for the fourth time to stay on until 2021, was paid less in 2017 than during the prior year. The CEO’s total compensation for fiscal 2017 (period ended September 2017) was $36.3 million, marking a fall of 17% from his fiscal 2016 compensation. Disney disclosed the executive compensation details in a regulatory filing.

Jim Parsons' form of closure came in knowing that there was nothing that could've been done to prevent his father's death. "When he comes through, he is having me reference to his passing and he is having me talk about wanting anyone to let go of this idea that there could have been a medical response any faster," Tyler insisted. context_meta.title: Pilot News: The Flash Vet Joins God, Teen Wolf Star's False Profits and More
context_meta.summary: The Flash's Violett Beane is taking on a new gig in the Berlanti-verse. The actress will star opposite The Mayor's Brandon Micheal Hall in the CBS dramedy pilot God Friended Me, from Flash producer Greg Berlanti, our sister site Deadline reports. Beane — who recurs on the aforementioned CW series as speedster Jesse Quick — will play a confident and quick-witted online magazine writer whose life takes an interesting turn when she meets Miles (Hall), an outspoken atheist who is “friended” by God. context_meta.summary: I spy Season 9 of FXX's Archer airing this spring. Archer: Danger Island, the penultimate season of the animated comedy, will premiere on Wednesday, April 25 at 10/9c. This upcoming season follows seaplane pilot Sterling Archer (voiced by H. Jon Benjamin) and his co-pilot Pam (voiced by Amber Nash) as they survive on the South Pacific island of Mitimotu in 1939. Ready for more of today's newsy nuggets? Well… * Billy Eichner is getting his first comedy special on Netflix, which is expected to include music and Billy on the Street segments, THR.com reports. A premiere date has not been announced. * Starz will be airing a Counterpart Season 1 marathon, beginning at 12:35 pm on Sunday, March 25,

context_meta.title: ABC orders Alec Baldwin talk show, sneak peek set to air post-Oscars
context_meta.summary: Alec Baldwin is jumping from Saturdays to Sundays. An Emmy winner for his time on Saturday Night Live as Donald Trump, Baldwin has officially landed a talk show at ABC, EW has confirmed. The network has ordered eight episodes for later this year, but a sneak peek of Sundays with Alec Baldwin will air after this Sunday's Academy Awards and feature sit-downs with Jerry Seinfeld and Kate McKinnon. “I'm excited about this show and grateful to ABC for taking a chance on me in what is, admittedly, a crowded field,” Baldwin said in a statement. “I've enjoyed doing my podcast for WNYC and look forward to the challenge of doing a show on camera.” “Alec's intellect, wit and wealth of life experience afford

context_meta.title: Apple adds an M. Night Shyamalan thriller to its roster of original shows
context_meta.summary: Apple will apparently have every kind of show from anyone with any kind of name working in Hollywood when it launches its updated approach to original video content: The latest original on its slate is a 10-episode, half-hour thriller series order that will be executive produced by M. Night Shyamalan, who is also going to direct the first installment (via Variety). The thriller is being written by writer Tony Basgallop, who wrote 24: Live Another Day and 24: Legacy (so he is familiar with action-packed TV productions). There's not much else we know about the show at this stage, beyond that it's described as a "psychological thriller," which makes sense given that Shyamalan is attached.

context_meta.title: Sarah Shahi returning for season-ending arc on 'Chicago Fire'
context_meta.summary: Sarah Shahi is slated to return to Chicago Fire for a season-ending arc. The Person of Interest alum will reprise her role as Renée Royce for at least three episodes at the end of season, EW has learned exclusively. Shahi first appeared on the NBC drama in season 1, when her character was rescued by Firehouse 51 after a car accident. Renée became romantically entailed with Severide (Taylor Kinney), though they quickly broke it off when she moved to Spain. She briefly returned in season 2 with news that she was pregnant, but when it turned out to not be Severide's baby, the duo broke up for good. context_meta.summary: As the creative minds behind Marvel's Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D. get ready to fine-tune the Season 5 finale, steps are being taken to see that it also satisfies as a series finale, should the ABC drama not get renewed. “We are in process [of writing the finale],” co-showrunner Jed Whedon told TVLine on Saturday at the show's Episode 100 celebration. Added co-showrunner Maurisa Tancharoen: “We know what it is.” And what it is, Tancharoen said, could serve as “either” a season or series finale. Whedon elaborated, “Yeah, we're ready for if this is the end. context_meta.title: Ratings: CBS’ ‘Living Biblically’ Not Off to a Hell of a Good Start
context_meta.summary: The Jay R. Ferguson sitcom didn’t find a ton of faithful viewers with Monday’s debut, especially in the key 18-49 demographic. NBC’s “Good Girls” fared far better, though it had a nice lead-in with “The Voice” season premiere. NBC was first in ratings with a 2.3 rating/9 share in the advertiser-coveted demo and in total viewers with an average of 10.1 million, according to preliminary numbers.

context_meta.title: Arie Luyendyk Jr.'s Most Obnoxious Tweets From The Bachelor's "Women Tell All" Special
context_meta.summary: Arie Luyendyk Jr. didn't hold back during The Bachelor's "The Women Tell All" special. While there were certainly some shocking moments during the episode, there was just as much drama happening online. Before the episode aired, the 36-year-old race car driver posted one very shady tweet that left most of Bachelor Nation gasping for air and chugging their wine. "Bachelor in Paradise auditions wait I mean 'Women Tell All,'" he wrote alongside a photo of the women from his season making surprised faces. "Tune in tonight, good old fashioned drama," he added before referencing a few big moments from this season with the hashtags, "#TheBachelor #Kristaaaaaaaaal #Glamshame #Bloopers #MissingKids #YouKnowWhatYouDid"
